instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
This board is not creating this lines:

<SIGNAL>PP1V_SUS</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL>

according to me <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> should create those lines using some of the following that are present:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.70v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5 v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Not really true.
Did you check enable signal for these voltages?

<SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> yes, should appear; it is directly controlled by <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
But <SIGNAL>1V_SUS</SIGNAL> is enabled by power good signal from <SIGNAL>VCORE_SUS_PCH</SIGNAL>.

You should fix the <SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> problem first.
Check diode mode to ground at L8020.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
DIODE MODE
L8020 = ,393

<SIGNAL>PMIC_SHUTDOWN_L</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL> = 2.7V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_PMICLDO</SIGNAL> = 3,3V
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>P5VS4_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>P1V8SUS_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> = 3,3
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_READY</SIGNAL> = .063

THIS RAILS GO HIGH AND THEN DROP:

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S0_L</SIGNAL>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
You have <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>, but missing <SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL>.
Why do you need the other signals posted?

If no short at L8020, check <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR>/21/23.
If all good, change <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R8020</RESISTOR>/21/23 are good... replaced <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> still having the same issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Possibly broken traces under <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
Check if <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> arrive to its corresponding pads; <SIGNAL>1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> power supply.
